content.text:
The pipe flow in Fig. P6.52 is driven by pressurized air in the tank. What gage pressure p_1 is needed to provide a 20°C water flow rate Q = 60 m^3/h? <image 1>

A. 2.38E6 Pa
B. 2.61E5 Pa
C. 1.56E6 Pa

To determine the gage pressure \( p_1 \) needed to provide a 20°C water flow rate \( Q \), we can use the following steps:

1. Calculate the density of water at 20°C:
\[ \rho_w = 1000 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

2. Calculate the density of air at 20°C:
\[ \rho_a = 1.225 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

3. Calculate the density of the mixture:
\[ \rho_{m} = \rho_w + \rho_a = 1000 + 1.225 = 1012.5 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

4. Calculate the density of the water jet:
\[ \rho_{j} = \rho_w = 1000 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

5. Calculate the density of the air jet:
\[ \rho_{j} = \rho_a = 1.225 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

6. Calculate the density of the mixture jet:
\[ \rho_{j} = \rho_{m} = 1012.5 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

7. Calculate the density of the mixture jet:
\[ \rho_{j} = \rho_{m} = 1012.5 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]

\[ \rho_{j} = \rho_{m} = 1012.5 \, \text{kg/m}^3 \]
